metadata.case_name: Appellants v. State of Jammu and Kashmir

facts.text: Outside raiders began attacking Kashmir on October 22, 1947.
The State acceded to India on October 26, 1947.
Enemy Agents Ordinance, No. XIX of S. 2004 was enacted soon after in January 1948.
There was cease-fire on January 1, 1949 and the raids came to an end.
The present Enemy Agents Ordinance, No. VIII of S. 2005 became law on January 24, 1949.
Incidents out of which this prosecution arose took place on June 27 and 28, 1957.

Appellants are being prosecuted before a Special Court constituted under the Ordinance for offences under s. 3 of the Ordinance, ss. 3, 4 and 5 of the Explosive Substances Act, VI of 1908, s. 120-B of the Penal Code and s. 29 of the Public Security Act read with rr. 28 and 32 of the Rules thereunder.
Appellants filed Writ Petition No. 53 of 1957 in Jammu and Kashmir High Court, dismissed on 19th February 1958.
Section 5 of the Jammu and Kashmir Constitution Act, S. 1996 was repealed by an amending Act, No. XVII of S. 2005, passed on November 17, 1951.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Enemy Agents Ordinance, No. VIII of S. 2005 is unconstitutional as it violates Art. 14 of the Constitution.
Whether His Highness had legislative competence to promulgate the Ordinance under s. 5 of the Jammu and Kashmir Constitution Act, given the Instrument of Accession.
Whether the Ordinance came to an end upon repeal of s. 5 of the Jammu and Kashmir Constitution Act in 1951.
Whether the Ordinance has lapsed as the conditions under which it was enacted had become obsolete.
Whether the Ordinance is void as inconsistent with Art. 352 of the Constitution and following Articles.

petitioner_arguments.text: The Ordinance is unconstitutional as it violates Art. 14 of the Constitution by providing a special procedure different from ordinary criminal courts, amounting to discrimination.

There was no legislative competence in His Highness to issue the Ordinance under s. 5 of the Constitution Act, as His Highness had executed the Instrument of Accession on October 26, 1947 surrendering powers regarding Defence, Communications and External Affairs to the Government of India and the Ordinance came under the head Defence.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Instrument of Accession (Schedule items under Defence)

petitioner_arguments.text: Section 5 of the Constitution-Act was repealed by an amending Act, No. XVII of S. 2005, passed on November 17, 1951, and therefore the Ordinance also came to an end on the day s. 5 was repealed.
The Ordinance has in any case lapsed as the conditions under which it was enacted had become obsolete and do not exist any more.
The Ordinance was void as it was inconsistent with Art. 352 of the Constitution and the Articles following.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 352, Part XVIII of the Constitution

respondent_arguments.text: There was a reasonable classification founded on an intelligible differentia with rational relation to the object of the Ordinance, so not hit by Art. 14.
His Highness had legislative competence to promulgate the Ordinance; State retained powers to legislate on transferred subjects so long as not repugnant to Central laws; concurrent power exists.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Instrument of Accession; J&K Constitution Act s.5

respondent_arguments.text: Repeal of s. 5 of the Constitution-Act did not result in the Ordinance coming to an end, as s. 6 of the Jammu and Kashmir General Clauses Act saved it.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 14 forbids class legislation but permits reasonable classification founded on intelligible differentia with rational relation to object; Ordinance classifies enemy agents and those aiding enemy reasonably given circumstances of raids and subversion threat.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Classification reasonable; no discrimination; offences under s.3 are aggravated and may be treated differently.

court_reasoning.text: Ordinance not covered by Item 1 under Defence in Instrument of Accession Schedule; pith and substance is public order, criminal law and procedure, not armed forces.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Indirect impact on armed forces does not change pith and substance.

court_reasoning.text: Repeal of s.5 does not affect previous operation or things duly done thereunder per s.6(b) J&K General Clauses Act; Ordinance remains valid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Law enacted under competence continues till repealed.

court_reasoning.text: Ordinance is permanent legislation targeting subversion; cannot lapse without repeal even if conditions changed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Emergency was occasion, not condition for permanence.

court_reasoning.text: No inconsistency with Art.352 or Part XVIII; those provisions unrelated.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No connection between Ordinance and Emergency Provisions.

holdings.text: Ordinance not violative of Art.14; reasonable classification.
Ordinance within legislative competence of His Highness; not covered by ceded matters in Instrument of Accession.
Repeal of s.5 Constitution Act does not end Ordinance; saved by General Clauses Act.
Ordinance has not lapsed; permanent law.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sri Ram Krishna Dalmia v. Shri Justice S. R. Tendolkar
precedents_cited.relevance: Principles on Art.14 reasonable classification and discrimination by procedure.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Art.14 test for equality; others raised but not decided.

statutes_cited.name: Enemy Agents Ordinance, No. VIII of S. 2005
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged law; provides special procedure for trial of enemy agents.

statutes_cited.name: Jammu and Kashmir Constitution Act, S. 1996
statutes_cited.relevance: Authority for promulgation; repeal does not affect Ordinance.

statutes_cited.name: Jammu and Kashmir General Clauses Act, J.K. XX of S. 1977
statutes_cited.relevance: Saves Ordinance from repeal of enabling provision.

statutes_cited.name: Public Security Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences under which appellants prosecuted, read with rules 28 and 32.

statutes_cited.name: Enemy Agents Ordinance, No. XIX of S. 2004
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed and consolidated into present Ordinance.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers taken away from courts re Special Judges.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding the High Court's dismissal of the writ petition. The Enemy Agents Ordinance was held valid and not unconstitutional, competent, not lapsed, and prosecution of appellants to continue before Special Court.

key_quotes.text: Art. 14 forbids class legislation, it does not forbid reasonable classification for the purposes of legislation.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core test for validity under Art.14 applied to Ordinance.

key_quotes.text: In pith and substance therefore, the Ordinance deals with public order and criminal law and procedure the mere fact that there is an indirect impact on armed forces in s. 3 of the Ordinance will not make it in pith and substance a law covered by item 1 under the head Defence.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: Being a permanent law, it can only be brought to an end by means of repeal by competent authority.
key_quotes.speaker: court
